author: HCAndersen
text: THERE was once a sculptor, named Alfred, who having won the large gold medal and obtained a travelling scholarship, went to Italy, and then came back to his native land.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was young at that time- indeed, he is young still, although he is ten years older than he was then.

author: HCAndersen
text: On his return, he went to visit one of the little towns in the island of Zealand.

author: HCAndersen
text: The whole town knew who the stranger was; and one of the richest men in the place gave a party in his honor, and all who were of any consequence, or who possessed some property, were invited.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was quite an event, and all the town knew of it, so that it was not necessary to announce it by beat of drum.

author: HCAndersen
text: Apprentice-boys, children of the poor, and even the poor people themselves, stood before the house, watching the lighted windows; and the watchman might easily fancy he was giving a party also, there were so many people in the streets.

author: HCAndersen
text: There was quite an air of festivity about it, and the house was full of it; for Mr. Alfred, the sculptor, was there.

author: HCAndersen
text: He talked and told anecdotes, and every one listened to him with pleasure, not unmingled with awe; but none felt so much respect for him as did the elderly widow of a naval officer.

author: HCAndersen
text: She seemed, so far as Mr. Alfred was concerned, to be like a piece of fresh blotting-paper that absorbed all he said and asked for more.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was very appreciative, and incredibly ignorant- a kind of female Gaspar Hauser.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I should like to see Rome," she said; "it must be a lovely city, or so many foreigners would not be constantly arriving there.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now, do give me a description of Rome.

author: HCAndersen
text: How does the city look when you enter in at the gate?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "I cannot very well describe it," said the sculptor; "but you enter on a large open space, in the centre of which stands an obelisk, which is a thousand years old."

author: HCAndersen
text: "An organist!" exclaimed the lady, who had never heard the word 'obelisk.'

author: HCAndersen
text: Several of the guests could scarcely forbear laughing, and the sculptor would have had some difficulty in keeping his countenance, but the smile on his lips faded away; for he caught sight of a pair of dark-blue eyes close by the side of the inquisitive lady.

author: HCAndersen
text: They belonged to her daughter; and surely no one who had such a daughter could be silly.

author: HCAndersen
text: The mother was like a fountain of questions; and the daughter, who listened but never spoke, might have passed for the beautiful maid of the fountain.

author: HCAndersen
text: How charming she was!

author: HCAndersen
text: She was a study for the sculptor to contemplate, but not to converse with; for she did not speak, or, at least, very seldom.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Has the pope a great family?" inquired the lady.

author: HCAndersen
text: The young man answered considerately, as if the question had been a different one, "No; he does not come from a great family."

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is not what I asked," persisted the widow; "I mean, has he a wife and children?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "The pope is not allowed to marry," replied the gentleman.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I don't like that," was the lady's remark.

author: HCAndersen
text: She certainly might have asked more sensible questions; but if she had not been allowed to say just what she liked, would her daughter have been there, leaning so gracefully on her shoulder, and looking straight before her, with a smile that was almost mournful on her face?

author: HCAndersen
text: Mr. Alfred again spoke of Italy, and of the glorious colors in Italian scenery; the purple hills, the deep blue of the Mediterranean, the azure of southern skies, whose brightness and glory could only be surpassed in the north by the deep-blue eyes of a maiden; and he said this with a peculiar intonation; but she who should have understood his meaning looked quite unconscious of it, which also was charming.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Beautiful Italy!" sighed some of the guests.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, to travel there!" exclaimed others.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Charming!

author: HCAndersen
text: Charming!" echoed from every voice.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I may perhaps win a hundred thousand dollars in the lottery," said the naval officer's widow; "and if I do, we will travel- I and my daughter; and you, Mr. Alfred, must be our guide.

author: HCAndersen
text: We can all three travel together, with one or two more of our good friends."

author: HCAndersen
text: And she nodded in such a friendly way at the company, that each imagined himself to be the favored person who was to accompany them to Italy.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, we must go," she continued; "but not to those parts where there are robbers.

author: HCAndersen
text: We will keep to Rome.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the public roads one is always safe."

author: HCAndersen
text: The daughter sighed very gently; and how much there may be in a sigh, or attributed to it!

author: HCAndersen
text: The young man attributed a great deal of meaning to this sigh.

author: HCAndersen
text: Those deep-blue eyes, which had been lit up this evening in honor of him, must conceal treasures, treasures of heart and mind, richer than all the glories of Rome; and so when he left the party that night, he had lost it completely to the young lady.

author: HCAndersen
text: The house of the naval officer's widow was the one most constantly visited by Mr. Alfred, the sculptor.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was soon understood that his visits were not intended for that lady, though they were the persons who kept up the conversation.

author: HCAndersen
text: He came for the sake of the daughter.

author: HCAndersen
text: They called her Kaela.

author: HCAndersen
text: Her name was really Karen Malena, and these two names had been contracted into the one name Kaela.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was really beautiful; but some said she was rather dull, and slept late of a morning.

author: HCAndersen
text: "She has been accustomed to that," her mother said.

author: HCAndersen
text: "She is a beauty, and they are always easily tired.

author: HCAndersen
text: She does sleep rather late; but that makes her eyes so clear."

author: HCAndersen
text: What power seemed to lie in the depths of those dark eyes!

author: HCAndersen
text: The young man felt the truth of the proverb, "Still waters run deep:" and his heart had sunk into their depths.

author: HCAndersen
text: He often talked of his adventures, and the mamma was as simple and eager in her questions as on the first evening they met.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was a pleasure to hear Alfred describe anything.

author: HCAndersen
text: He showed them colored plates of Naples, and spoke of excursions to Mount Vesuvius, and the eruptions of fire from it.

author: HCAndersen
text: The naval officer's widow had never heard of them before.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Good heavens!" she exclaimed.

author: HCAndersen
text: "So that is a burning mountain; but is it not very dangerous to the people who live near it?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Whole cities have been destroyed," he replied; "for instance, Herculaneum and Pompeii."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Oh, the poor people!

author: HCAndersen
text: And you saw all that with your own eyes?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "No; I did not see any of the eruptions which are represented in those pictures; but I will show you a sketch of my own, which represents an eruption I once saw."

author: HCAndersen
text: He placed a pencil sketch on the table; and mamma, who had been over-powered with the appearance of the colored plates, threw a glance at the pale drawing and cried in astonishment, "What, did you see it throw up white fire?"

author: HCAndersen
text: For a moment, Alfred's respect for Kaela's mamma underwent a sudden shock, and lessened considerably; but, dazzled by the light which surrounded Kaela, he soon found it quite natural that the old lady should have no eye for color.

author: HCAndersen
text: After all, it was of very little consequence; for Kaela's mamma had the best of all possessions; namely, Kaela herself.

author: HCAndersen
text: Alfred and Kaela were betrothed, which was a very natural result; and the betrothal was announced in the newspaper of the little town.

author: HCAndersen
text: Mama purchased thirty copies of the paper, that she might cut out the paragraph and send it to friends and acquaintances.

author: HCAndersen
text: The betrothed pair were very happy, and the mother was happy too.

author: HCAndersen
text: She said it seemed like connecting herself with Thorwalsden.

author: HCAndersen
text: "You are a true successor of Thorwalsden," she said to Alfred; and it seemed to him as if, in this instance, mamma had said a clever thing.

author: HCAndersen
text: Kaela was silent; but her eyes shone, her lips smiled, every movement was graceful,- in fact, she was beautiful; that cannot be repeated too often.

author: HCAndersen
text: Alfred decided to take a bust of Kaela as well as of her mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: They sat to him accordingly, and saw how he moulded and formed the soft clay with his fingers.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I suppose it is only on our account that you perform this common-place work yourself, instead of leaving it to your servant to do all that sticking together."

author: HCAndersen
text: "It is really necessary that I should mould the clay myself," he replied.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah, yes, you are always so polite," said mamma, with a smile; and Kaela silently pressed his hand, all soiled as it was with the clay.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then he unfolded to them both the beauties of Nature, in all her works; he pointed out to them how, in the scale of creation, inanimate matter was inferior to animate nature; the plant above the mineral, the animal above the plant, and man above them all.

author: HCAndersen
text: He strove to show them how the beauty of the mind could be displayed in the outward form, and that it was the sculptor's task to seize upon that beauty of expression, and produce it in his works.

author: HCAndersen
text: Kaela stood silent, but nodded in approbation of what he said, while mamma-in-law made the following confession:- "It is difficult to follow you; but I go hobbling along after you with my thoughts, though what you say makes my head whirl round and round.

author: HCAndersen
text: Still I contrive to lay hold on some of it."

author: HCAndersen
text: Kaela's beauty had a firm hold on Alfred; it filled his soul, and held a mastery over him.

author: HCAndersen
text: Beauty beamed from Kaela's every feature, glittered in her eyes, lurked in the corners of her mouth, and pervaded every movement of her agile fingers.

author: HCAndersen
text: Alfred, the sculptor, saw this.

author: HCAndersen
text: He spoke only to her, thought only of her, and the two became one; and so it may be said she spoke much, for he was always talking to her; and he and she were one.

author: HCAndersen
text: Such was the betrothal, and then came the wedding, with bride's-maids and wedding presents, all duly mentioned in the wedding speech.

author: HCAndersen
text: Mamma-in-law had set up Thorwalsden's bust at the end of the table, attired in a dressing-gown; it was her fancy that he should be a guest.

author: HCAndersen
text: Songs were sung, and cheers given; for it was a gay wedding, and they were a handsome pair.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Pygmalion loved his Galatea," said one of the songs.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah, that is some of your mythologies," said mamma-in-law.

author: HCAndersen
text: Next day the youthful pair started for Copenhagen, where they were to live; mamma-in-law accompanied them, to attend to the "coarse work," as she always called the domestic arrangements.

author: HCAndersen
text: Kaela looked like a doll in a doll's house, for everything was bright and new, and so fine.

author: HCAndersen
text: There they sat, all three; and as for Alfred, a proverb may describe his position- he looked like a swan amongst the geese.

author: HCAndersen
text: The magic of form had enchanted him; he had looked at the casket without caring to inquire what it contained, and that omission often brings the greatest unhappiness into married life.

author: HCAndersen
text: The casket may be injured, the gilding may fall off, and then the purchaser regrets his bargain.

author: HCAndersen
text: In a large party it is very disagreeable to find a button giving way, with no studs at hand to fall back upon; but it is worse still in a large company to be conscious that your wife and mother-in-law are talking nonsense, and that you cannot depend upon yourself to produce a little ready wit to carry off the stupidity of the whole affair.

author: HCAndersen
text: The young married pair often sat together hand in hand; he would talk, but she could only now and then let fall a word in the same melodious voice, the same bell-like tones.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was a mental relief when Sophy, one of her friends, came to pay them a visit.

author: HCAndersen
text: Sophy was not, pretty.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was, however, quite free from any physical deformity, although Kaela used to say she was a little crooked; but no eye, save an intimate acquaintance, would have noticed it.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was a very sensible girl, yet it never occurred to her that she might be a dangerous person in such a house.

author: HCAndersen
text: Her appearance created a new atmosphere in the doll's house, and air was really required, they all owned that.

author: HCAndersen
text: They felt the want of a change of air, and consequently the young couple and their mother travelled to Italy.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Thank heaven we are at home again within our own four walls," said mamma-in-law and daughter both, on their return after a year's absence.

author: HCAndersen
text: "There is no real pleasure in travelling," said mamma; "to tell the truth, it's very wearisome; I beg pardon for saying so.

author: HCAndersen
text: I was soon very tired of it, although I had my children with me; and, besides, it's very expensive work travelling, very expensive.

author: HCAndersen
text: And all those galleries one is expected to see, and the quantity of things you are obliged to run after!

author: HCAndersen
text: It must be done, for very shame; you are sure to be asked when you come back if you have seen everything, and will most likely be told that you've omitted to see what was best worth seeing of all.

author: HCAndersen
text: I got tired at last of those endless Madonnas; I began to think I was turning into a Madonna myself."

author: HCAndersen
text: "And then the living, mamma," said Kaela.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, indeed," she replied, "no such a thing as a respectable meat soup- their cookery is miserable stuff."

author: HCAndersen
text: The journey had also tired Kaela; but she was always fatigued, that was the worst of it.

author: HCAndersen
text: So they sent for Sophy, and she was taken into the house to reside with them, and her presence there was a great advantage.

author: HCAndersen
text: Mamma-in-law acknowledged that Sophy was not only a clever housewife, but well-informed and accomplished, though that could hardly be expected in a person of her limited means.

author: HCAndersen
text: She was also a generous-hearted, faithful girl; she showed that thoroughly while Kaela lay sick, fading away.

author: HCAndersen
text: When the casket is everything, the casket should be strong, or else all is over.

author: HCAndersen
text: And all was over with the casket, for Kaela died.

author: HCAndersen
text: "She was beautiful," said her mother; "she was quite different from the beauties they call 'antiques,' for they are so damaged.

author: HCAndersen
text: A beauty ought to be perfect, and Kaela was a perfect beauty."

author: HCAndersen
text: Alfred wept, and mamma wept, and they both wore mourning.

author: HCAndersen
text: The black dress suited mamma very well, and she wore mourning the longest.

author: HCAndersen
text: She had also to experience another grief in seeing Alfred marry again, marry Sophy, who was nothing at all to look at.

author: HCAndersen
text: "He's gone to the very extreme," said mamma-in-law; "he has gone from the most beautiful to the ugliest, and he has forgotten his first wife.

author: HCAndersen
text: Men have no constancy.

author: HCAndersen
text: My husband was a very different man,- but then he died before me."

author: HCAndersen
text: "'Pygmalion loved his Galatea,' was in the song they sung at my first wedding," said Alfred; "I once fell in love with a beautiful statue, which awoke to life in my arms; but the kindred soul, which is a gift from heaven, the angel who can feel and sympathize with and elevate us, I have not found and won till now.

author: HCAndersen
text: You came, Sophy, not in the glory of outward beauty, though you are even fairer than is necessary.

author: HCAndersen
text: The chief thing still remains.

author: HCAndersen
text: You came to teach the sculptor that his work is but dust and clay only, an outward form made of a material that decays, and that what we should seek to obtain is the ethereal essence of mind and spirit.

author: HCAndersen
text: Poor Kaela! our life was but as a meeting by the way-side; in yonder world, where we shall know each other from a union of mind, we shall be but mere acquaintances."

author: HCAndersen
text: "That was not a loving speech," said Sophy, "nor spoken like a Christian.

author: HCAndersen
text: In a future state, where there is neither marrying nor giving in marriage, but where, as you say, souls are attracted to each other by sympathy; there everything beautiful develops itself, and is raised to a higher state of existence: her soul will acquire such completeness that it may harmonize with yours, even more than mine, and you will then once more utter your first rapturous exclamation of your love, 'Beautiful, most beautiful!'"
